title: Rename dynamicHelpers to dynamicLocals()
body: phasing out the whole "helper" thing for 3.0

title: Possible to support multiple rendering engines?
body:
Hey Guys,

For an upcoming app I'm wanting to have the views in any of the following markup languages: markdown, textile, haml, html, whatever. Then after that run them through a template engine like: eco or ejs

Though I'm not really sure how to go about this. I'd imagine in the end being able to do something like `something.md.eco`, `something.md` and just `something` with the missing parts as system defaults would be nice. Another requirement I gather would be specifying the order of the template engines, for instance you would want eco to run first, then the markdown parser.

The markdown example is nice, but I do require markdown files (or textile, whatever) to be parsed through a template engine rather than just variable interpolation.

title: Move / refactor router from connect
body: im moving connect's router into express, it's becoming far to specific to express to be general purpose anymore, and its really annoying editing connect _just_ for express. It will remain in connect until the next major release

title: app.param load function called once for each middleware
View cache breaks with vhosts (somewhere between 2.2.0 and 2.2.1)
body:
I have an app which is using connect.vhost to redirect to a few express servers and after updating express I noticed an issue with view being read from the wrong server.

My setup is something like this:

vhosts.js 
a/server.js
a/views/index.js
a/views/athing.js
b/server.js
b/views/index.js
b/views/bthing.js

Where vhosts.js is a simple connect server, running through cluster with these vhosts:
- a.example.com -> a/server.js
- b.example.com -> b/server.js

I guess the problem is that both servers have a view like "./views/index.js". It seems it attempts to render the view of the server that was visited first, no matter which one of the servers you visit, which causes a crash because both servers don't use the same locals and well, it's just the wrong view being rendered.

Could it be that the cache is not using an absolute path for the views? And it used to before 2.2.1?

title: Remove app.helpers() res.helpers()
body: in favour of app.locals() / res.locals(), they are the same but to many names makes things more confusing

title: view partials variable passing scope problem
body:
i.e. Using EJS, In caller template: <%- partial('comment', comments);%> In partial template: <% for (i in comments) { %>
  • <%= comments[i] %>
    • <% } %> If an array variable "comments" are both accessible in template and partial template, items in array "comments" will be printed |comments|*|comments| times, if the partial template iterates the array. A solution would be using following instead: partial('comment');

title: expressjs breaks node's res.writeHead
UTF-8 defaults for JSON and JSONP
body: JSON and JSONP default to UTF-8 in the same way as HTML. Introduces app.set('charset') to set charset default at the application level. Closes #632.

title: JSON / JSONP responses should default to UTF-8
body: Behavior should be the same as HTML, defaults or not. Adding res.charset on every repsonse is a PITA. Setting something like app.set('charset', 'utf-8') might be nice.

title: Partial lookup should check _ first
body: for example if you have `./edit` and `./_edit` the latter should take precedence

title: Add list of all app options to documentation
body: The documentation lacks options such as 'view cache' and 'tips'. These should be added.

title: Inconsistency in guide (or missing documentation)
body:
I noticed the following in the guide:

```
app.enable('view cache');
app.enabled('view cache');
```

Unfortunately after snooping around in the source, I noticed the setting is actually called `cache views`.

That being said, it would be nice that this option be documented in the guide.

On the other hand, wouldn't `view cache` be more consistent with the other view settings?

title: auto set Content-Type in res.attachement
req.download detection problem?
body:
Currently, after doing some more testing, I found out that expressjs still doesn't cast the callback if I were to do this action below
- Simple download server
- Request download using chrome
- After sometime, before the download finished, I clicked chrome cancel button
- I even close chrome
- No callback with error! - Here is the problem

Without better detection, I can't do much stuff after the user download a file from my server. If i were to create a delete file after download routine, I need a download detection system which can differentiate the users action, if they were to cancel, lost connection, or finished download.

I wanted my delete file after download routine to just delete the file if the users fully finished downloading the file and not if their connection is lost or canceled or any other else.

title: express can support CDN for static resources?
body: express can support CDN for static resources,for example:css,js,images etc.. for DEV i'm want use '/public' directory as the static resource, but for PROD i'm want use the other server for static resources serve. for example:http://static.myhost.com/images/logo.jpg.

title: Add include() helper to inline a view's contents
body: sometimes people want to use partial() to simply include a template, however this is less efficient since it requires extra render calls.

title: Have app.param() support querystring/request bodies/and route segments
body: It would be great to have app.param() functions triggered in all three cases handled in req.param() (parameters in req.params, req.query and req.body).  Thanks!

title: omit paths from session storage
body: It should be possible to omit all of the urls under a certain path from hitting the session. A use case might be a pure data path which has no use for knowing about the session or caring. This would prevent the session from being loaded and saved to update the access time.

title: Haml compiles to string and not function
body:
I created an empty express app with `express -t haml -c sass` and added a simple index.haml file. On rendering I get a an error on `express/2.1.0/package/lib/view.js` line 343 that there's no method `call` on template.

I used node-inspect to have a look at that piece of code and found that when using jade `template` is a function (which of course has `call`) and when using haml `template` is a string.

I'm very new to JS and am at the end of the line. I'd like to use haml for my project since Im familiar with it, but I also could work with jdae. But I think if there's a bug it should be fixed :)

Versions:
express -v 2.1.0
npm -v 0.2.11-5
node -v v0.4.2
haml@0.2.5 
hamljs@0.5.1  (not sure if this is used at all...)

Thanks! :)

title: Consider becoming a request handler only
execute configuration callbacks in definition order
Template named constructor.xyz, prototype.xyz etc
body:
Ive template named constrotor.ejs In express 1.x it works fine. 

```
res.render('constructor', {
    current_path: '/constructor/',
    layout: 'main_layout'
});
```

But in express 2.x+ it throws error

```
TypeError: Object function Object() { [native code] } has no method 'indexOf'
at View.resolveEngine (/usr/local/lib/node/.npm/express/2.2.0/package/lib/view/view.js:85:22)
at new View (/usr/local/lib/node/.npm/express/2.2.0/package/lib/view/view.js:48:22)
at ServerResponse._render (/usr/local/lib/node/.npm/express/2.2.0/package/lib/view.js:288:21)

at pass (/usr/local/lib/node/.npm/connect/1.2.1/package/lib/middleware/router.js:164:10)
at Object.router [as handle] (/usr/local/lib/node/.npm/connect/1.2.1/package/lib/middleware/router.js:17                     0:6)
```

Problem is in cache.basename[path]

```
exports.basename = function(path){
  return cache.basename[path]
    || (cache.basename[path] = basename(path));
};

cache.basename['constructor'] // yep its exists and it is an Object. String expected.
```

title: multiple layouts & disabled by default
body:
I don't use site-wide layouts a whole lot, so I get tired of typing `layout: false` in every route. Instead I think it would be cool if layout was disabled by default, but it could be enabled really easily by putting something like `layout: 'mycoollayout'` and it would point to /views/mycoollayout.jade or whatever. 

What do you think?

title: response.render locking up subsequent requests with EJS
redirect for http server when behind https proxy
body:
Found some interesting behavior in the absolute res.redirect(...) when serving an express http server behind a https nginx proxy. I looked at the code and see that for absolute redirects it creates the url with http:// host .. etc etc ... this causes the nginx proxy to redirect to https again (since all my traffic must be https).

What would be the best way to make the force the url to be: https ? Note that the express server itself is http but it sits behind a https proxy for all requests.

title: Add api to return route callbacks

for example:

```
app.get('/foo') => Function
app.all('/foo') => [Function, Function]
```

title: app.param to accept multiple middleware?
body:
Is it possible to allow app.param() to accept multiple middleware function parameters like app.get|put|post|etc?

As part of my "preconditions", sometimes I don't want to automatically try and load something from my database when the user isn't logged in, especially since I need information about my logged in user in order to perform the lookup. For now, I'm having to manually check the session and then call next() within app.param().

title: Renderer
body:
I just separated the `render` and `partial` logic into a Renderer module.

Methods `res.render|partial` call to that Renderer and then do the `send` with the results.

This way, we can use again partials in our helpers without getting mutable headers errors.

I tried some of the examples and all of them work. I also added an example that is not working on the master branch.

I was not able to run the tests...

This was just a prototype, so feel free to change the style, remove or add anything.

title: Remove need for app.set() to get a setting
body: currently if you want to inherit settings we need to call `app.set(foo)` to grab a setting, but on app.set(key, val) we can easily use accessors so that `app.settings.foo` will be equivalent, allowing us to expose a `settings` local to views without ugly `set('foo')` calls

title: Add app, req & res to options for views
body: View template engines should have access to app, req & res inside their locals. This patch just adds .app, .res and .req to the locals passed to the view. Similar to the 1.x options.scope.

title: res.local persisting through redirects
SlowBuffers are not handled correctly with send.
body:
When using your canvas project, sending a canvas buffer (which is a SlowBuffer in node) results in a json object being sent. The following patch to respond.js appears resolve this issue. 

```
71c71
<       if (Buffer.isBuffer(body)) {

---
>       if (body instanceof Buffer) {
90c90
<     this.header('Content-Length', Buffer.isBuffer(body)

---
>     this.header('Content-Length', body instanceof Buffer
```

title: middleware linkage should not be order dependant
static handler should be available for routes
Issue #580
body: This is the pull request associated with [Issue 580](https://github.com/visionmedia/express/issues/#issue/580).

title: res.app and req.app aren't restored when nested handlers call `out()`
body:
The `res.app` and `req.app` properties are set by the first entry in the middleware stack (see Server() constructor). When a nested server context is entered, the `.app` property is changed, but it's not restored when the nested `Server.handle()` calls `out()`.

See [this gist](https://gist.github.com/869889) for an example. The example code can be run against 1.x or 2.x to demonstrate the error.

I have made [a patch](https://github.com/weaver/express/commit/3f2d54ffffe2c0590143b213528e7bc82fe14e87), see associated pull request.

I encountered this problem originally when I tried to use some of my `app.helpers()` in a 404 view. Since the `res.app` has been replaced, the 404 template fails to resolve some of its bindings.

title: add HTTPSServer to exports
body:
needed for https://github.com/visionmedia/express-namespace/pull/1 to work.
could be useful to others, too?

title: Tiny docs change
body:
Connect 1.0's static middleware doesn't support anymore setting the root inside the options hash.

Wasted some time on this one while migrating since it wasn't mentioned in the migration guide. Since I found this line in the guide I didn't suspect a thing. I suggest also doing one of the following:
1. Mentioning it in the migration guide
2. Add support for the old syntax in static() for backwards compliance
3. Add a check in static() that fails when someone tries to pass an options hash as the "root" parameter.

If you want, you can reply with your preference and I can create a new pull request with it.

title: Allow for kwargs
body:
It would be nice to support kwargs (ala Python) in express.

For instance, currently I have to write this:

```
res.render 'home',
    locals:
          artists: artists
```

but if kwargs were allowed then I could also write this instad:

```
res.render 
    view: 'home'
    locals:
          artists: artists
```

I find kwargs quite natural in a lot of cases. Check out a js implementation [here](http://jsfiddle.net/seanmonstar/WfWhN/) from [seanmonster](http://seanmonstar.com/post/3746460491/function-kwargs) as an example (maybe not a great one, not sure myself).

This is a relatively audacious request so I'm thinking it'll only happen if you fancy kwargs yourself. I think it's worth mentioning.

title: Load partial by variable name instead of string literal
body:
It appears that loading partials by a variable instead of a string literal is impossible? 

```
  - each artist in artists
    section(id:artist.slug)
      h1= artist.name
      .content
        -var partial_name = artist.slug.replace('-','_')
        -console.log(partial_name)
        != partial('catherine_colvey')
        != partial('helene_joy')
        != partial('guy_sprung')
        != partial('beat_berwger')
        != partial('vanya_rose')
```

Instead of typing out each of their names manually and rethinking my loop therefore, I'd prefer to be able to just use a variable int the loop to choose the right partial. When I do so an error is thrown however:

```
Error: EBADF, Bad file descriptor '/Users/KUHRT/code/at-the-bottom-of-the-hill/views/index.jade'
    at Object.openSync (fs.js:200:18)
    at Object.readFileSync (fs.js:91:15)
    at Partial.contents (/usr/local/lib/node/.npm/express/2.0.0beta2/package/lib/view/view.js:121:13)
    at ServerResponse.render (/usr/local/lib/node/.npm/express/2.0.0beta2/package/lib/view.js:286:30)
    at render (/usr/local/lib/node/.npm/express/2.0.0beta2/package/lib/view.js:94:16)
    at renderPartial (/usr/local/lib/node/.npm/express/2.0.0beta2/package/lib/view.js:114:12)
    at Object.partial (/usr/local/lib/node/.npm/express/2.0.0beta2/package/lib/view.js:270:12)
    at Object.<anonymous> (eval at <anonymous> (/usr/local/lib/node/.npm/jade/0.8.3/package/lib/jade.js:227:10))
    at Object.anonymous (eval at <anonymous> (/usr/local/lib/node/.npm/jade/0.8.3/package/lib/jade.js:227:10))
    at ServerResponse.render (/usr/local/lib/node/.npm/express/2.0.0beta2/package/lib/view.js:287:24)
```

I am assuming this error is because the partial is not found.

Am I trying to do something impossible?

title: Can't set headers after they are sent.
body:
With beta version of express I am getting the follow error:

```
Error: Can't set headers after they are sent.
    at ServerResponse.<anonymous> (http.js:504:11)
    at ServerResponse.setHeader (/usr/local/lib/node/.npm/connect/1.0.3/package/lib/patch.js:39:15)
    at /usr/local/lib/node/.npm/connect/1.0.3/package/lib/middleware/errorHandler.js:72:19
    at [object Object].<anonymous> (fs.js:86:5)
    at [object Object].emit (events.js:39:17)
    at afterRead (fs.js:843:12)
```

My app.js file is as follows:

```
express = require 'express'
app = express.createServer()
#stylus = require 'stylus'

#stylusCompiler = (str, path, fn)->
    #stylus(str).
    #set('filename', path).
    #set('compress', no).
    #render(fn)

app.configure 'development', ->
    app.use express.errorHandler
        dumpExceptions: yes
        showStack: yes

    #app.use stylus.middleware
        #src: "#{__dirname}/stylus"
        #dest: "#{__dirname}/public"
        #compile: stylusCompiler

app.configure 'production', ->
    app.use express.errorHandler()

app.configure ->
    app.set 'view engine', 'jade'
    app.set 'view options', {
        layout: false
    }
    app.use express.static "#{__dirname}/public"



db = require './models'
app.get /^\/{1}$/, (req,res)->
    db.artists.find {}, (err,artists)->
        res.render 'home', {
            #locals:
                #artists: artists
        }







app.listen '8888'
```

title: idea: take layout from closest available from view
body:
e.g. say I have this:

```
res.render("reports/myreport");
```

Could Express look for layout.jade (or whatever) in the reports directory before looking at the parent directory (w/out having to define the layout in every render call).

Just a thought, saw what you did with partials for Express 2 and like that, thought this may help make layouts more convenient.

title: Backported connect version requirement fixes from 1.0.8 to 1.0.7
body:
This should allow people to use npm to install Express 1.0.7 for node 0.4.x apps. The connect requirement got fixed in 1.0.8, but that also added a restriction to node versions less than 0.4.0.

I know Express 1.x is only listed as compatible with node 0.2.x, but up until recently people have been able to use Express in their 0.4.x apps. This patch just restores that ability for 1.0.7. I don't know if this is not in keeping with your plans for people to migrate to 2.x, but it seems to be causing problems for people... not being able to use 1.x in their 0.4.x where they were able to before.

I also don't know what you'd release this as... I pushed it to the npm registry as tfe-express@1.0.7-1. Maybe express@1.0.7-1?

title: Response.Download emit callback without error even when the file isn't fully finished?
body:
Just now, I saw that download accelerator is no longer supported by expressjs. This is a critical problem for my application. Is there a fix to this? or is there anything that I miss-looked? - This has been stated as wrong by my users, maybe you can check it?

One more thing is, even though the file isn't 100% downloaded, the response.download is still emitting the callback without error. Again, a critical error. - This has also been stated wrong by my users, maybe you can also check it?

I really hope that you can fix this. I'm using the latest expressjs from master.
If this is not an error, just close it and sorry for it.

title: How to stop this error?
body:
```
Error: Can't remove headers after they are sent.
    at ServerResponse.removeHeader (http.js:537:11)
    at Socket.<anonymous> (..../express.master/lib/response.js:204:19)
    at Socket.emit (events.js:59:20)
    at Array.<anonymous> (net.js:799:27)
    at EventEmitter._tickCallback (node.js:108:26)
```

Here some info :
at response I used response.header('cache-control', 'no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate');

title: Can't use mutable header APIs after sent
body:
Searched through the issues and found another (555) about this, but I am experiencing a completely different error with the 2.0 beta, perhaps related to interaction with Mongoose. I have an asynchronous call to to Mongoose's find() method to load a bunch of User objects. Inside the callback I am calling render on the response and then send the list of users to the view. This works fine when visiting the page for the first time. However, on any subsequent visit to the URL, node crashes with an error.

The stack trace and relevant code snippet are shown in this gist: https://gist.github.com/856844

title: require('connect').middleware returns undefined
body: After an update to the latest connect (1.0.3) my express applications fail.

title: Cannot use array function names in query string
body:
I had a query string parameter named 'sort', so when I tried to get the param value using: 
req.param('sort');
and I was surprised to get a function back instead of the param value I'm looking for, this also applies to all function names in the 
Array.prototype
I traced back the code to https://github.com/visionmedia/express/blob/master/lib/request.js#L142 where the function is trying to find the query in the route params, and instead of falling back to query string, it returns the array function found. Thanks, Amjad Masad

I've mentioned in the past ... it would be useful to have Rails style local partials ... e.g. "_sidebar.jade"  that would sit in the same folder as the current view. --- as opposed to having a big catchall "partial" folder in the root (which becomes unwieldily after about 6 partials) 
ThoughttS ?
